DOC.HEAD: Social Security Pushing for Faster Catastrophic Refunds
DOC.TEXT: Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King is supporting a plan under which the government early next year would mail monthly refunds to millions of elderly people overcharged for Medicare premiums. If the plan goes through, Social Security beneficiaries who unavoidably will be overcharged by about $5.30 a month for their Medicare coverage early in 1990 will be simultaneously issued monthly refund checks. The overcharges are the result of Congress' late action in repealing Medicare's catastrophic health-care program. Social Security contends its computers can't be adjusted by January to halt withholding of the extra Medicare premium for catastrophic coverage. As a result, nearly 27 million Social Security beneficiaries who have Medicare premiums deducted directly from their benefit checks are expected to be overcharged from January through May. Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King said Tuesday a panel of experts convened by the agency to study the problem suggested issuing monthly or bimonthly refund checks to offset the overcharges, or sending out lump-sum refunds late in the spring. Mrs. King said the Treasury Department, which actually issues Social Security checks, reported that lump-sum refunds were the most feasible option and that monthly refund checks would be ``much worse than the other two scenarios.'' However, Mrs. King said Treasury did not expressly rule out the possibility of mailing monthly refunds, so she will ``send back a signal that that would be our preferred option.'' She said she would ask Treasury to advise her on whether it can provide monthly checks. ``That option ... appears to be the best way to get money back as quickly as possible,'' Mrs. King said in an interview. ``My purpose has been to try to make the beneficiaries whole. They should not have to pay for this problem. The question is how can we get them this money.'' Andy Montgomery, a spokesman for Treasury's Bureau of Financial Management Services, said the agency has been meeting with Social Security ``to identify the most expeditious way to achieve the refunds. At this particular point, nothing has been decided.'' Social Security initially had said it probably would issue the refunds in lump sums late in the spring. Mrs. King's statement that she would push for monthly refunds came on the same day that two congressmen sent President Bush a letter asking him to support that option. Reps. David Bonior, D-Mich., and Robert Wise, D-W.Va., said retirees should not have to pay _ even temporarily _ for a program that won't exist next year. ``For seniors, this isn't just a matter of principle _ it's a matter of meeting rent payments, buying food and paying utilities,'' Bonior said. Bonior said the General Accounting Office estimated the cost of issuing monthly refunds at $25 million to $30 million, and said the first refund checks could be in the mail by February. Mrs. King said each extra monthly mailing would cost about $10 million.
